texts.shortText: A small species of kelp with sporophytes only about 1 m tall. Holdfast conical and made up of a tangle of branching root-like haptera. Stipe solid and cylindrical, typically about 50 cm tall, giving rise to elongate primary blade from which shorter secondary blades branch laterally. Both primary and secondary blades with prickly surface and bearing reproductive sori.
Total length typically about 1 m, but may reach 2 m in deeper waters.

Global: South Africa, New Zealand, Australia, Canary Islands, Cape Verde Islands, Senegal, Madagascar, Oman.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana Bay.

Found in deep intertidal pools and on shallow reefs along the south coast, but also in deeper waters (10-30 m) in False Bay and as far east as Sodwana Bay in northern KwaZulu-Natal, where extends to 60 m depth.
Alternating generations of the familiar large spore-producing sporophytes and separate microscopic male and female gametophytes.
Could be confused with small E. maxima, but has a solid stipe and prickly rather than smooth fronds and is absent from west coast.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Bolton, JJ & Anderson, RJ (1987). Temperature tolerances of two southern African Ecklonia species (Alariaceae, Laminariales) and of hybrids between them. Marine Biology, 96, 293-297.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 386).

De Clerck, O, Bolton, JJ, Anderson, RJ & Coppejans, E (2005). Guide to the seaweeds of KwaZulu-Natal. Scripta Botanica Belgica, 33, 1-294 (p. 122).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 192).
